newsitem.title: GHANA: Ivory Coast streamlines mine permit approvals.
newsitem.headline: Ivory Coast streamlines mine permit approvals.

text.p: Ivory Coast has set up a National Mining Commission (COMINE) to speed up mining permit approvals and handle environmental impact studies, Ivory Coast's mines minister said on Friday.
"For investors it is a one-stop contact point grouping together concerned ministries," Minister of Mines and Energy Mohammed Lamine Fadika told Reuters. "The first files will be handled from Monday."
Exploration permit requests would be processed in 45 days or less, Fadika said at the sidelines of Oil and Gas Africa 1997, a three day forum in Accra ending on Friday.
COMINE had been loosely modelled on neighbouring Ghana's Mines Commission and would also handle other matters including duty-free imports of equipment, said Fadika.
Mining policy has up until now been handled mainly by the Direction des Mines, with decisions passed up to the Ministry of Mines and Energy.
Gold exploration companies in Ivory Coast welcomed the move.
"Anything that cuts red tape is welcome," said one exploration geologist based in Abidjan. "They say at the moment permits take six weeks to approve but it is usually longer than that."
Ivory Coast has only two operating gold mines with a third due to open in 1997. A wave of prospectors have arrived since the introduction of a new mining code in 1996.
"Ghana (mining sector policy) is far more streamlined so the Mines Commission is a good model," said the geologist.
Others said customs agents had refused to grant waivers on equipment, despite industry complaints to government officials.
"There are rules on duty-free imports in the (mining) code but when you apply to customs for rebates they just say any items had to be declared at the time of permit approval," one said.
Foreign advisers in Abidjan last week told Reuters Ivorian mine policy management was about to be tightened up after industry complaints about red-tape slowing exploration efforts.
Existing rules and regulations stemming from the Mining Code would not be changed but management procedures would be tightened up, government advisers in Abidjan told Reuters.
About 24 companies, holding over 55 exploration permits are now operating in Ivory Coast, which shares Ghana's Birimian greenstone gold bearing geology.
Ivory Coast produces less than three tonnes of gold a year. Ghana, the regions largest producer, produces around 40 tonnes a year.
Gold exploration in West Africa has picked up sharply in the 1990s.
Prospectors are also busy in Mali, Guinea and Burkina Faso.
